title: Jennifer Arcuri: five unanswered questions after TV interview
text:
Jennifer Arcuri, the woman whose friendship with Boris Johnson has placed her at the centre of a growing political storm, gave her first live broadcast interview on Monday, speaking to ITV’s Piers Morgan and Susanna Reid for almost an hour. Despite the length of the exchange, though, significant questions remained for the prime minister.

1. Why did Johnson fail to declare an interest over Arcuri and her companies when he was mayor of London?

During her interview, Arcuri refused nine times to answer direct questions about whether she had an intimate relationship with Johnson. But she also made it clear that she shared a “very close bond” with the then mayor of London. Johnson told The Andrew Marr Show last week that he had no interest to declare over Arcuri. But her comments on Monday suggest otherwise. She confirmed he visited her flat (where she said her office was also based) a “handful” of times, that they joked about pole dancing, talked about Shakespeare and technology, and that he spoke for free at four of her events. Despite the closeness of the relationship, Johnson’s register of interests as mayor makes no mention of Arcuri or her companies.

2. Why did Johnson’s office intervene to give Arcuri a place on trade missions to Tel Aviv and New York after she was initially told she did not meet the criteria?

Arcuri suggested the initial decision to refuse her place was due to an overly restrictive interpretation of the criteria. She was initially refused a place on a technology trade trade trip to Singapore and Malaysia in 2014 because her company, Innotech, was an events company not a technology company. To get round this requirement she was allowed on the trip as representative of her new video technology company, Playbox, even though it had been trading less than the required 12 months necessary to qualify for a place.

London and Partners [L&P], the mayor’s promotion agency, which ran the trip, said it was not unusual for the rules to be waived in this way. But this exception made for Arcuri on the Singapore trip does not explain why she was subsequently allowed on trade missions to Tel Aviv and New York. Despite not qualifying for these events, L&P said one of the mayor’s advisers said she should be allowed a place.

Arcuri on Monday insisted she was vetted by an “extremely fierce” woman in charge of the trips. “She didn’t let me pass because I was Boris’s friend. She wanted to know that I was actually doing real business there and spent time learning about me.” Her answer still does not explain why one of Johnson’s advisers intervened on Arcuri’s behalf for the trade trips to New York and Tel Aviv.

3. Why did the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) approach Arcuri’s company before awarding her new company, Hacker House, £100,000 earlier this year?

Lots of questions have already been asked about how much the DCMS did to verify whether Hacker House was genuinely a UK company before awarding it £100,000 from a scheme aimed at fostering digital skills in this country. Arcuri insisted the company was based in the UK and had eight UK staff when the money was awarded. But she also claimed the DCMS suggested she should apply for the funds in the first place.

She said: “They came to us and said, ‘Hey, we have this pot of money.’ And I said: ‘Wow, you have a pot of money to do exactly as we are doing with the technology we were building.’ Why wouldn’t you fund us?” She insisted Johnson had “absolutely nothing to do with my grant”. She was not asked why the DCMS approached her to apply, but she suggested officials were worried that not enough companies were applying for the funds.

She said: “My company has developed an extremely effective hands on hacking course, that allows people to enter industry based on the skills they achieve in my course. This is a massive problem across the UK and the United States. DCMS were far more concerned with fulfilling that quota and that need, so they came to us.”

4. Why did Arcuri claim that Johnson wrote her a letter of recommendation to run a tech quango?

Arcuri told ITV that her then friend Milo Yiannopoulos, the rightwing commentator, suggested she apply for the job of chief executive of Tech City, an organisation set up by Downing Street to champion technology companies in London. She suggested to ITV that she went along with the idea to humour Yiannopoulos.

But the Sunday Times reported that Arcuri boasted of still having a letter of recommendation from Johnson. It quoted an email from her as saying “I still have the letter of rec from Boris. Hahaha. To think that we asked him to write us a recommendation for the CEO of Tech City is just hysterical.” On Monday she said: “That letter doesn’t exist.” Asked to explain the email, she said she was “just playing along”.

5. Why did Johnson speak at four Innotech events for free when he rarely spoke at other tech events?

Other companies organising tech conferences in London at the time were puzzled by why Johnson only seemed to talk at Arcuri’s event. She claimed he chose to attend her events on merit, saying: “It made him look like a rock star within the tech community … I produce really good, very sexy, chic, on-point, thought-leading events. There was no other events series like Innotech, none.”

She continued: “I always made sure that Boris got a win out of my events … Every event that he came to had a strategic advantage for him.” But it is still unclear what strategic advantage Johnson gained. When he spoke at the launch event of Innotech in 2012, Arcuri admitted “jaws hit the floor when he showed up”. She suggested Johnson was doing it to secure her participation in his 2012 reelection campaign as mayor, saying: “When he left, he said, ‘Jenn, see you on the Boris bus,’because I told him if you come to this, I’ll help with your campaign.”
description: Questions remain about Boris Johnson’s relationship with businesswoman after her ITV appearance
